members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In December 2012, the Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) requested 
policy and advisory technical assistance (TA) from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to 
provide policy and implementation guidance on the introduction of social worker services into 
social assistance programs.1 ADB undertook TA reconnaissance in April 2012 and reached 
agreement  with  the  government  regarding  the  TA’s  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  terms  of 
reference  for  consulting  services,  cost  estimates,  financing  plan,  and  implementation 
arrangements.2 The TA is in line with the PRC country partnership strategy, 2011–2015, which 
emphasizes inclusive growth and balanced urban development, and responds to goals set forth 
in the Twelfth Five-Year Plan.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  The social assistance systems established in the PRC, including dibao (minimum living 
standard guarantee scheme), aim to protect the fundamental rights and interests of vulnerable 
groups by focusing on areas such as family care, child education and health, livelihoods, and 
mental  health  of  family  members.  While  common  in  social  assistance  programs  in  many 
countries, the concept of "social workers" is relatively new in the PRC. Emerging service areas 
include medical social workers who facilitate patients’ access to and use of medical facilities, as 
well as follow-up care. Unlike medical patients, beneficiaries of welfare programs such as dibao 
have no such case workers helping them to access other services, benefits, or programs. The 
Ministry of Civil Affairs (MOCA) has identified the lack of assistance provided by social workers 
to help address beneficiaries’ household needs and access to services, such as employment, 
as one important factor inhibiting beneficiaries who are able to work from transitioning from 
dibao to employment. To bridge the gap between welfare and work and to ensure and create a 
professional system of social work services for beneficiaries, MOCA intends to introduce and 
expand the role of social workers in social assistance. Helping MOCA define the role and 
qualifications necessary for social workers in social assistance is the focus of the proposed TA 
activities.  
 
3.  The  goal  of  building  a  cadre  of  professional  social  workers  in  social  assistance  is 
supported by the National Medium- and Long-term Talent Development Plan (2010–2020),4 
which calls for an increase in the number of social workers in the PRC to 2 million by 2015 and 
3 million by 2020. At present, approximately 80,000 people have passed the accreditation test 
for professional social workers in the PRC. Based on international and domestic experience, 
introducing professional social work services into social assistance is important for enhancing 
awareness  of  employment  opportunities  for  beneficiaries,  increasing  their  social  inclusion, 
protecting them from being rejected by society, and improving welfare assistance service quality. 
Despite  efforts  to  date  to  increase  the  numbers  of  social  workers,  challenges  remain  in 
integrating social work services into social assistance, including the following: 
 
(i)  Poorly defined field of study. The field of social work remains poorly defined. 
The  job  area  is  poorly  defined  due  to  a  wide  range  of  activities  that  are 
undertaken by social workers in the PRC and the varying levels of professional 
training available for each of those roles (professional social workers versus

paraprofessional social workers). This TA provides an opportunity to help define 
the role of social workers for MOCA, particularly in social assistance.  
(ii)  Gap  between  academic  training  and  practice.  There  is  a  significant  gap 
between the academic training and practice of social work in the PRC. There are 
currently more than 220 majors in universities in the PRC dedicated to social 
work, and this number is growing. Despite this, the majority of program graduates 
do not pursue work in the field, and those who do face many challenges due to 
lack of practical training, internships, and occupational and social recognition. 
Given the growing demand for social workers within the government and other 
service  providers  as  well  as  community-based  groups, this TA  comes  at  an 
opportune moment to engage with academic institutions on applied research 
defining  qualifications,  practical  training,  and  emerging  models  for  service 
provision. 
(iii)  Lack of social workers trained to provide services for work promotion and 
related  services  for  dibao  recipients  and  their  families.  Although  social 
workers in many countries support the transition from welfare to work, social 
workers in the PRC have limited training in social assistance tasks, such as 
providing services to recipients to find jobs and transition from welfare to work. 
Institutionally, the role of social workers in this area is yet to be defined by MOCA, 
and the TA findings will play a significant role in providing the evidence and 
experience through scoping studies to fill this gap.5 
(iv)  Need  for  greater  integration  between  government  and  civil  society-led 
social work activities. There are many social work activities in the PRC that are 
supported by social workers through civil society organizations (CSOs), such as 
migrant worker services, disaster relief, youth development, elderly care, and 
health services. However, current legislation and funding modalities can prevent 
CSOs from playing a greater role in government-led or contracted social work 
initiatives,  which  prevents  CSOs  from  providing  these  services  and  also 
contributes to a lack of institutional support for social workers in the field.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
4.  The  TA  aims  to  contribute  to  the  improvement  of  social  assistance  through  the 
introduction of social work services. Specifically, the TA intends to achieve the following goals: (i) 
identify areas for involving social workers in social assistance programs through the assessment 
of gaps in the needs of poor households as well as through the creation of services to support of 
the transition from welfare to work; and (ii) develop strategies and instruments for introducing 
social work services and accredited social workers into social assistance programs. 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
5.  The TA impact will be improved service delivery of social workers in government social 
assistance programs in the PRC. The outcome will be better knowledge and information in 
MOCA to enhance the service delivery of social workers in social assistance, as follows (i) 
professional guidelines provided to MOCA for consideration by September 2015, and (ii) a 
policy  paper  on  social  worker  integration  in  social  assistance  provided  to  MOCA  for 
consideration by September 2015. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
                                                
5  ADB. 2010. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for Building Equitable Opportunities into Social 
Assistance. Manila. One of the main policy recommendations from this TA was to provide social worker support for 
dibao recipients to facilitate their movement from welfare to work.

3 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
6.  The TA outputs will be (i) a gap analysis and needs assessment, policy, and 
implementation  recommendations;  (ii) an  international  study  tour  exploring 
institutional arrangements and workflows in professional social work institutions; 
and  (iii)  scoping  studies  on  the  introduction  of  social  workers  into  social 
assistance.6 A policy note and one knowledge product presenting key findings 
and major policy and implementation recommendations of the TA will be shared 
with  local  and  national  decision  makers  at  a  final  workshop  that  will  widely 
disseminate  and  discuss  the results.  A final  report  will  bring  all  the outputs 
together and provide an executive summary of the TA findings.  
 
7.  The TA will be implemented in three phases over a 24-month period. Phase 1, lasting 
4 months, will comprise a preliminary assessment and analysis of  the PRC’s existing system of 
social work and social assistance policies and strategies, including a review of international best 
practices. The analysis will make use of the policy paper and knowledge products generated by 
three previous ADB TA projects on social assistance.7 The consultant team will (i) design a 
research  plan,  including  methodology,  key  research  questions,  budget,  and  schedule;  (ii) 
identify scoping study issues and locations; (iii) identify international study tour locations; (iv) 
participate in workshops and seminars organized by the executing agency; (v) conduct field 
visits; and (vi) write reports and recommendations based on the investigation and goals of the 
TA.  Phase  2,  which  will  last  for  14  months,  will  (i)  conduct  the  gap  analysis  and  needs 
assessment  of  local  agencies focusing  on (a) the  transition from  welfare  to  work;  (b) the 
targeting of  working-age and able-bodied beneficiaries; and (c) the identification of practical 
gaps in the system where trained social workers could help; (ii) conduct an international study 
tour focused on best practices in social work service delivery in social assistance; and (iii) 
design scoping studies based on the results of the gap analysis and needs assessment. Phase 
2  will  include  a  workshop  to  present  the  findings  and  receive  feedback,  guidance,  and 
agreement on policy and implementation recommendations from the working group. Phase 3, 
lasting 6 months, will (i) finalize all the reports and policy and implementation recommendations; 
(ii) conduct a final workshop on findings and recommendations; (iii) prepare the policy note for 
decision makers; and (iv) prepare and disseminate the final reports and knowledge product.  
 
8.  The final workshop will invite participants from local governments, key ministry officials, 
donors, and research organizations operating in the PRC and  elsewhere to share the TA 
findings and recommendations. A final report of the workshop will be produced. All outputs will 
be provided in English and Chinese, and translation and publication costs will be included in the 
research costs. 
 
                                                
6  The specific focus of the scoping studies will be determined in consultation with ADB following the gap analysis 
and needs assessment. 
7  ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for Strengthening the Antipoverty Effects of 
Social Assistance. Manila (TA 7438-PRC); ADB. 2010. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for 
Building Equitable Opportunities into Social Assistance. Manila (TA 7702-PRC); ADB. 2012. Technical Assistance 
to the People’s Republic of China for Performance Evaluation Model for Urban and Rural Subsistence Security 
System. Manila (TA 8095-PRC). These TAs demonstrate that support has been holistically developed and 
implemented within the social assistance sector framework. Following the recommendations of TA 7438-PRC, 
which highlighted the need for performance monitoring and valuation, both TA 7702-PRC and TA 8095-PRC 
focused on strengthening different aspects of social assistance programs in the PRC. TA 8095-PRC is exploring 
the role of CSOs and NPOs in the implementation and monitoring processes of social assistance, which could 
provide an additional space for the social worker support.

4     
9.  Assumptions include: (i) the government remains committed to including social workers 
in  social  assistance;  (ii)  provincial  and  local  governments  adopt  the  recommendations; 
(iii) MOCA and the central government maintain the political will to ensure the integration of 
social workers in social assistance; (iv) MOCA has strong and stable implementation capacity; 
(v) MOCA supports the recommendations of the TA; (vi) necessary data and information are 
available; (vii) the draft final report is of good quality and suited locally to serve as the basis for 
review by the government; (viii) effective coordination of MOCA, the Department of Social 
Assistance (DSA), consultants, and researchers; (ix) effective participation and coordination 
with key stakeholders; and (x) the TA will be implemented as designed.  
 
10.  Risks include (i) key questions, options, and international best practice examples are not 
understood at the outset; (ii) local government agencies are unable or unwilling to change 
existing  systems  quickly;  and  (iii)  local  government  agencies  are  unable  or  unwilling  to 
participate in scoping studies.  
 
11.  Given the dynamic nature of the PRC’s economy, society, and demographic profile, the 
TA consultants will address these risks by conducting research in tandem with local civil affairs 
agencies,  labor  agencies,  civil  society  organizations,  and  other  groups  that  address 
beneficiaries’ needs. The work will be done in a participatory and consultative manner with all 
relevant stakeholders, which include the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF) and the 
Chinese Academy of Social Sciences.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $450,000 equivalent, of which $400,000 will be financed on 
a  grant  basis  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-other  sources).  The 
government  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  office  space  and  equipment 
(computers),  communications  facilities  for  consultants,  remuneration  and  per  diem  for 
counterpart staff, and other in-kind contributions. The TA will finance (i) consulting services, 
including field work and gap analysis and needs assessment; (ii) a conference and workshops; 
(iii) printing and dissemination of policy notes and the knowledge product; and (iv) a study tour. 
Details of the cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.   
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  The TA will be implemented over a period of 24 months from 15 November 2013 to 15 
November 2015. MOCA will be the executing agency for the TA and the DSA will be the 
implementing agency. A DSA employee will be designated as the TA focal point and will be 
responsible  for  day-to-day  oversight  and  support  of  the  consultants’  work.  The  DSA  will 
organize  institutional  arrangements  and  coordinate  local  staff  for  the  research  in  selected 
counties and cities. The DSA will also provide a suitably furnished office with computers, utilities, 
telecommunication access (including a broadband internet connection), materials, maps, data, 
and documents as required under the TA, and will cover the cost of office utilities for the 
consultants. 
 
14.  A total of 25 person-months of consulting services (two international consultants totaling 
2 person-months and two national consultants totaling of 23 person-months) will be required. 
The individually hired consultants will have expertise in (i) the design of social work programs 
and policies, particularly in support of the transition from welfare to work; (ii) existing social 
assistance and social work programs in the PRC, institutional frameworks, and monitoring and 
evaluation systems; and (iii) human resources management in social assistance and social work

5 
programs in the PRC. A national consultant will serve as the team leader. The consultants will 
be responsible for producing the TA’s outputs and deliverables effectively and on time, as well 
as organizing and carrying out all TA activities, including the analyses, study tour, scoping 
studies, symposiums and workshops, and policy note and knowledge product. ADB will create 
an internal review group of technical experts and team leaders from the East Asia Department, 
PRC  resident  mission,  Regional  and  Sustainable  Development  Department,  and  others 
responsible for similarly themed TA projects to ensure inputs from social protection specialists 
and facilitate cross-regional learning. A working group will be set up comprising representatives 
from government ministries and CSOs, including UNICEF and the Chinese Academy of Social 
Sciences, to review and provide guidance for the research team from inception. 
 
15.  In dialogue with MOCA and/or the DSA, ADB will recruit national and international 
experts to provide inputs as consultants. ADB will endorse the terms of reference, including the 
duration  and  expected  results.  The  consultants  will  be  selected  based  on  their  academic 
qualifications and relevant work experience.  All consultants under the TA will be selected in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines in the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to 
time).  Proceeds  of  the  TA  will  be  disbursed  in  accordance  with  the  Technical  Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). To facilitate implementation, 
ADB may establish an advance facility for MOCA as needed and/or utilize direct payment (e.g., 
for workshop venues). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION  
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Strategies for Involving Social Workers in 
Social Assistance, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

10  Appendix 3 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
1.   A  total  of  25  person-months  of  consulting  services  on  an  intermittent  basis  (two 
international  consultants  totaling  2  person-months  and  two  national  consultants  totaling 
23 person-months) will be required. The national consultant on social work and protection will be 
the team leader of the group of consultants. The international consultants will serve as advisors to 
the Ministry of Civil Affairs (MOCA) and the national consultants. Consultants will be recruited 
through individual selection, in accordance with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time).  
 
A.  Team Leader and Social Work Specialist (national, 17 person-months, intermittent) 
 
2.  The team leader and social work specialist will have strong expertise in (i) the design of 
social work programs and policies, particularly in support of the transition from welfare to work; (ii) 
existing social assistance and social work programs in the People’s Republic of China (PRC), 
institutional  frameworks,  and  monitoring  and  evaluation  systems;  and  (iii)  human  resources 
management in social assistance and social work programs in the PRC. The expert will have at 
least 10 years of relevant experience and a master’s degree in social work, social protection, 
public management, or other related disciplines. The expert must have an excellent command of 
English. Funds are available in the technical assistance (TA) to hire one research assistant to 
support research activities. Detailed tasks are as follows: 
(i)  serve as the team leader of the national and international consultants, and ensure 
timely completion of all outputs of the TA;  
(ii)  carry out gap analysis and needs assessment to critically review ongoing social 
work activities in the PRC, focusing on (a) assessing the institutional capacity, 
roles, and responsibility of each line agency involved; (b) social assistance and the 
transition  from  welfare  to  work,  targeting  working-age  and  able-bodied 
beneficiaries; and (c) practical gaps in the system that could benefit from social 
workers; 
(iii)  carry  out  evaluation  of  social  workers  in  employment  services  and  benefits 
services in the PRC; 
(iv)  prepare  a  report  on  international  and  PRC  experience  and  best  practices  in 
integrating social workers into social assistance activities; 
(v)  organize an international study tour investigating the integration of social workers 
in social assistance; 
(vi)  coordinate studies based on the gap analysis and needs assessment to support 
the integration of social workers in social assistance; 
(vii)  organize at least three workshops to discuss findings from assessments and policy 
and implementation recommendations; 
(viii)  prepare one knowledge product on the role of social workers in social assistance 
for MOCA and the policy note of TA recommendations; 
(ix)  prepare the policy recommendations for MOCA on suggested reforms; and  
(x)  prepare the final TA report. 
 
B.  Deputy Team Leader and Public Management Training Specialist (national, 6 person-
months) 
 
3.  The national public management training specialist will have strong expertise in (i) the 
design of public management programs and policies, particularly in supporting social assistance 
and social work; (ii) existing social work training programs in the PRC, institutional frameworks, 
and monitoring and evaluation systems; and (iii) experience in designing and managing scoping

development, or other related disciplines. The expert must have an excellent command of English. 
Detailed tasks are as follows:  
(i)  support gap analysis and needs assessment to critically review ongoing social 
work activities in the PRC, focusing on social assistance and the transition from 
welfare to work, targeting of vulnerable groups, and practical gaps in the system 
that could benefit from social workers; 
(ii)  participate in the design and implementation of scoping studies based on the gap 
analysis and needs assessment to support the integration of social workers in 
social assistance; 
(iii)  run  a  consortium  of  academic  experts  to  provide  advice  on  practical  training 
experience to social workers; 
(iv)  participate in workshops and provide inputs to knowledge product and reports; and  
(v)  assist the team leader in the timely completion of the TA outputs, as required. 
 
C.  Senior Social Work or Protection Specialist (international, 1 person-month) 
 
4.  The international senior social work specialist will have strong international expertise in 
international social assistance and social work programs, institutional frameworks, and monitoring 
and evaluation systems. The expert will have at least 12 years of relevant experience and a 
master’s degree in social work, social protection, public management, or other related disciplines. 
The  expert  must  have  relevant  work  experience  and  in-depth  knowledge  of  existing  social 
assistance and social work programs in the PRC. Detailed tasks are as follows:   
(i)  identify and study international best practices in social work, targeting training for 
and integration in social assistance; 
(ii)  help define the methodology for gap and needs assessment and scoping studies; 
(iii)  identify international study tour locations and institutions; 
(iv)  assist  the  team  leader  in  organizing  scoping  research,  implementation,  and 
workshops; 
(v)  act  as  a  resource  person  during  the  final  workshop  on  findings  and 
recommendations; 
(vi)  organize an international study tour investigating the integration of social workers 
in social assistance;  
(vii)  prepare brief report highlighting the lessons learned in the study tour; and  
(viii)  assist the team leader in preparing the final report. 
 
D.  Senior Tertiary Education Specialist (international, 1 person-month) 
 
5.  The international senior tertiary education specialist will have strong expertise in (i) the 
design of public management programs and policies, particularly in supporting social assistance 
and  social  work;  and  (ii)  in-depth  knowledge  of  international  social  work  training  programs, 
institutional frameworks, and monitoring and evaluation systems. The expert will have at least 12 
years of relevant experience and a master’s degree in social work, social protection, public 
management,  education,  or  other  related  disciplines.  The  expert  must  have  relevant  work 
experience in the PRC. Detailed tasks are as follows:  
(i)  identify and study international best practices in social work training; 
(ii)  contribute to the design of scoping studies; 
(iii)  act  as  a  resource  person  during  the  final  workshop  on  findings  and 
recommendations; and  
(iv)  assist the team leader in preparing the final report.
